titleInfo.title: A new map of the Cherokee nation and brief account of the negotiation.

mods.abstract: Top: A new map of the Cherokee nation with the names of the towns and rivers they are situated on. Engraved from an Indian draught by T. Kitchin."

This map appeared as an illustration for an article on a 1759 British-Cherokee treaty negotiation that was published in the March, 1760 issue of London Magazine. It depicts the location of the same Cherokee settlements shown on the Thomas Mante map, but with a more accurate geographic orientation. As a note on the map explains, it mistakenly identifies today's Tennessee River as the Mississippi. While it does not show the location of Fort Loudon or other British outposts, it does show the location of a set of waterfalls on today's Hiwassee River in eastern Tennessee. British colonial officials believed that these falls represented the closest point to the Carolina colonies that French traders and soldiers coming from the Ohio River might reach by boat. The British feared that French incursions could win the Cherokee away from their existing alliance with the British. Our copy of this map bears the pencilled notes "1760" and "$5.00," indicating that this copy had been offered for sale on the antiquarian market."
